content: Hi! I am writing "The Rust Performance Book". It's a mini-book similar to The Async Book (github, published) and the API Guidelines book (github, published).

I think it will be useful to many people, and I would like it to end up on GitHub under https://github.com/rust-lang/perf-book, and published at https://rust-lang.github.io/perf-book/. (Those links currently are dead.)
Any suggestions on what process I should follow to get that to happen?
E.g. I could create a project on my personal GitHub, and then, assuming people are happy with it, get it transferred to the rust-lang GitHub.
maybe ask #t-lang/doc if you don't get a response here
tho I think general gets pretty much everyone
@njn I think publishing that under t-compiler/performance auspices makes sense

njn said:

E.g. I could create a project on my personal GitHub, and then, assuming people are happy with it, get it transferred to the rust-lang GitHub.

This is the way :smile:. If people like it (make a post on Reddit/both discord/IRLO/URLO/here when you consider "good enough to start") you can then see about moving it to rust-lang/perf-book :smile:

Good luck on this though, it seems like a lot a work to write such a book !
but maybe it has a slightly different audience, not sure

@simulacrum That channel is about rustc's performance, right? This is a general "how to write fast Rust code" book. (It will have a subsection on improving compile times, but that's not the main topic.)
People in t-compiler/performance are probably interested but I don't think they are the only ones at all
hm, ok

I think I would suggest that we start it outside rust-lang then and once we have some fairly complete thing we can reconsider, I expect it to be a t-compiler question still though. You could also open a t-compiler MCP today proposing this, I suspect
or, perhaps, even a dev-tools question?
but nevertheless general policy on this sort of thing is to start outside rust-lang and then we can figure out how to move it in at a later point

the main thing we'd want as a rust org from moving something in are:

  • what are you seeking from rust org (i.e., why move it in)
  • what benefit do you expect this to provide to the rust org
super excited to see this though!
@simulacrum what is a "t-compiler MCP"?
https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/new?assignees=&labels=major-change%2C+T-compiler&template=major_change.md&title=%28My+major+change+proposal%29
but I suspect it might be too early for that even
but if you do decide to file one, I would start with the seeking/benefit questions for sure :)
I don't know why t-compiler would be particularly involved in this sort of project at all.
There's not really a good Rust Project team for this. The docs team no longer exists. You could work on it outside of the teams though.
And if and when it becomes good enough to ship, we can add it to the Rust Bookshelf, but I don't know who is the executive on that anymore? The core team?

Compiler is maybe "best fit" at present, since this is kind of documenting some of the ways to use rustc and profiling tools to uncover data -- but I agree the fit is imprecise (I'd have to review the contents though)

oliver said:

tho I think general gets pretty much everyone

(I at least don't monitor general so I wouldn't make that assumption :)

I am close to finished on my first draft of the Rust Performance Book. I will create https://github.com/nnethercote/perf-book/ in the next day or two. I would also like to put a built version of the book online, e.g. at https://nnethercote.github.io/perf-book/, but I'm not sure how to do that.
https://github.com/rust-lang/async-book has a built version at https://rust-lang.github.io/async-book/, I'd like to do much the same...
Hmm, maybe https://github.com/peaceiris/actions-gh-pages#%EF%B8%8F-mdbook-rust will do it?
Yep the mdbook actions is what you are looking for
Right, I see https://github.com/Veykril/tlborm/blob/master/.github/workflows/gh-pages.yml is doing that, I'll probably cargo-cult that

Hmm. I have put the book at https://github.com/nnethercote/perf-book. I setup the gh-pages.yml file and it appears to be deploying correctly -- I see generated HTML in the gh-pages branch at https://github.com/nnethercote/perf-book/tree/gh-pages.
and it's live! https://nnethercote.github.io/perf-book/
It is? I get a 404...
it works for me - maybe the 404 is cached?
I just tried a different browser, 404 there too...
that's so strange image.png
Same in Safari
maybe you have the DNS cached and github is playing dns games?
O_o

$ dig nnethercote.github.io
nnethercote.github.io.  3599    IN  A   185.199.108.153
Site loads for me.
Oh, https://nnethercote.github.io/perf-book/index.html works for me
/me scratches head
Screen-Shot-2020-11-17-at-1.35.25-pm.png
The book looks nice so far.

https://github.community/t/index-html-not-working/10256/25 discussed this, lots of answers, I tried one of the simple ones (switch the page branch to master and then back to gh-pages) and it seems to have worked! I can now see it at https://nnethercote.github.io/perf-book/
yay
oooh I need to try DHAT on rustdoc
(context: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/79103)
